title: Point 1
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Accesses* all necessary elements of grid (in any order, no bounds error)

* An enhanced for loop inherently accesses all elements of an ArrayList

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int numRows = 0;
   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)
   {
      int orderCount = 0;
      for (int c = 0; c < grid[r].length - 1; c++)
      {
         if (grid[r][c].length() <= grid[r][c + 1].length())
         {
            orderCount++;
         }
      }
      if (orderCount == grid[r].length - 1)
      {
         numRows++;
      }
   }
   return numRows;
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • fail to access all elements of a row after determining the row is not in order
  • return early, as long as bounds and indices would otherwise support accessing all necessary elements

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access an element of grid correctly
  • access rows but fail to access the elements within the rows
  • have a bounds error when accessing adjacent elements

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • fail to access all elements of a row after determining the row is not in order
  • return early, as long as bounds and indices would otherwise support accessing all necessary elements

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access an element of grid correctly
  • access rows but fail to access the elements within the rows
  • have a bounds error when accessing adjacent elements

title: Point 2
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Calls length() to obtain the length of a string element from the 2D array

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int numRows = 0;
   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)
   {
      int orderCount = 0;
      for (int c = 0; c < grid[r].length - 1; c++)
      {
         if (grid[r][c].length() <= grid[r][c + 1].length())
         {
            orderCount++;
         }
      }
      if (orderCount == grid[r].length - 1)
      {
         numRows++;
      }
   }
   return numRows;
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access elements of grid incorrectly
  • fail to call length() as long as the length is computed correctly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • call any String method incorrectly

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access elements of grid incorrectly
  • fail to call length() as long as the length is computed correctly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • call any String method incorrectly

title: Point 3
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Determines whether a 2D array element is at least as long as another 2D array element (body of control flow statement must not be empty)

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int numRows = 0;
   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)
   {
      int orderCount = 0;
      for (int c = 0; c < grid[r].length - 1; c++)
      {
         if (grid[r][c].length() <= grid[r][c + 1].length())
         {
            orderCount++;
         }
      }
      if (orderCount == grid[r].length - 1)
      {
         numRows++;
      }
   }
   return numRows;
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access the length of a string incorrectly
  • attempt to access an out-of-bounds index
  • compare non-adjacent elements
  • use incorrect logic for the condition (e.g., > in place of >=)

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access the lengths of the string elements

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • access the length of a string incorrectly
  • attempt to access an out-of-bounds index
  • compare non-adjacent elements
  • use incorrect logic for the condition (e.g., > in place of >=)

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to access the lengths of the string elements

title: Point 4
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Accumulates count within a conditional statement within a loop

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()

   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)

descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • identify rows incorrectly
  • fail to initialize the count variable or initialize it incorrectly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • increment count without a conditional statement

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • identify rows incorrectly
  • fail to initialize the count variable or initialize it incorrectly

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • increment count without a conditional statement

title: Point 5
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Identifies rows that are ordered from shortest to longest string (algorithm)

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int numRows = 0;
   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)
   {
      int orderCount = 0;
      for (int c = 0; c < grid[r].length - 1; c++)
      {
         if (grid[r][c].length() <= grid[r][c + 1].length())
         {
            orderCount++;
         }
      }
      if (orderCount == grid[r].length - 1)
      {
         numRows++;
      }
   }
   return numRows;
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • confuse rows with columns
  • access the length of a string incorrectly
  • count the in-order pairs in a row, as long as the count is used to correctly identify whether the entire row is in order

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to initialize, maintain, or reset variable used to identify an individual row
  • fail to compare necessary adjacent elements
  • use incorrect logic for the condition (e.g., >= in place of >)

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • confuse rows with columns
  • access the length of a string incorrectly
  • count the in-order pairs in a row, as long as the count is used to correctly identify whether the entire row is in order

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • fail to initialize, maintain, or reset variable used to identify an individual row
  • fail to compare necessary adjacent elements
  • use incorrect logic for the condition (e.g., >= in place of >)

title: Point 6
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria or to score the response.

To earn this point, responses must demonstrate the following:

  • Determines and returns count of identified rows (algorithm)

Canonical Solution:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int count = 0;
   for (String[] row : grid)
   {
      boolean rowInOrder = true;
      for (int j = 1; j< row.length; j++)
      {
         if (row[j - 1].length() > row[j].length())
         {
            rowInOrder = false;
         }
      }
      if (rowInOrder)
      {
         count++;
      }
   }
   return count;
}

Alternate Canonical:

public int countOrderedRows()
{
   int numRows = 0;
   for (int r = 0; r < grid.length; r++)
   {
      int orderCount = 0;
      for (int c = 0; c < grid[r].length - 1; c++)
      {
         if (grid[r][c].length() <= grid[r][c + 1].length())
         {
            orderCount++;
         }
      }
      if (orderCount == grid[r].length - 1)
      {
         numRows++;
      }
   }
   return numRows;
}
descriptions:
The response does not earn the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • incorrectly identify whether each row meets criteria
  • fail to initialize or reset variable used to identify an individual row

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • confuse rows with columns
  • fail to compare elements
  • fail to return the determined value
  • fail to initialize variable used to count identified rows
  • print the count instead of or in addition to returning it
  • modify grid

The response earns the point.

Responses can still earn the point even if they

  • incorrectly identify whether each row meets criteria
  • fail to initialize or reset variable used to identify an individual row

Responses will not earn the point if they

  • confuse rows with columns
  • fail to compare elements
  • fail to return the determined value
  • fail to initialize variable used to count identified rows
  • print the count instead of or in addition to returning it
  • modify grid
